discourse_list.title: Clarifications about my take on LOVE vs MetaDAO, and a diagram of approval voting

content.content: I’ve chatted with both Rune and Luca separately, I would say I have ‘friendly’ relations with each, and both of them seem willing to collaborate in good faith to work through this. First of all my recent statements in chat about “securing supermajority vote” should not be interpreted like there is some coalition with a specific agenda, there is not, this was intended as a provocative statement to highlight that useless overpaid delegates who talk a lot are in a small minority and can simply be ignored. Second, I inferred that the borrower was voting Yes on the LOVE proposal because 1) it was a big change structural change and 2) it was done at the same time as a massive borrow took place on Aave. Borrowing to vote “no change” is not a sustainable play, it only makes sense to do it if you can use it to gain some kind of ground. Third, the timing of the different attacks against me and against the Rai system made it seem very much like it was coming from people who were not happy with the fact that I was interrupting this vote, which made me further think it was coming from the “yes” side. I realize now those attacks might have actually not come from either of these sides, and that actually it is some completely external threat. All that said, I want to emphasize that I am not in favor of the MetaDAO proposal any more than I am in favor of the LOVE proposal. I think both are under-developed and possibly existentially bad moves. I think at this point we need to step back and not make ANY drastic actions until we solve the core problem that governance here is completely dysfunctional, and that can be done by reducing complexity and clarifying how the current voting system actually works at the core. In one of my angrier posts I said something like “why don’t you guys let me and Rune design a better collateral onboarding system”, but now I see that as being misinterpreted to mean I support his particular endgame proposal. That’s not true, what I should have said it “I want to figure out who is a good-faith contributor and who is a sockpuppet, and design something without getting divide-and-conquered by shills who talk all day but don’t make or do anything.” What is clear to me now is that neither of these proposals has “broad” approval. This is exactly the outcome that you can expect when governance is a simple majority vote system! Here I made a little diagram showing roughly how I intended the governance contract to be used. It is very rough, don’t take it as a complete description of either Maker nor any new system. I made it to emphasize just one thing, which is that approval voting was always my intended design, and the result is that the system is resistant to governance attacks and is not constantly preoccupied with contentious political proposals. Right now we need it more than ever. (Here “old model” and “new model” is in the context of my new projects – here we would be adopting something like the “old model”, because Maker is rooted in the ds-chief contract).  Screen Shot 2022-07-30 at 5.08.57 PM3262×1798 466 KB  The good news is again that the system is still grounded in the ds-chief contract, and it can still safely be transitioned to a state where approval voting is used to then also select delegates. With a set of broadly supported core system delegates, we can start untangling this mess without every single vote being split down the middle based on essentially political lines. I think we should do this before committing to a direction for RWA onboarding policy (but I don’t object to small case studies with responsibly low debt ceilings so that progress is not totally stalled). I can try to lead by example and show what approval voting for a set of delegates looks like in vivo in parallel projects for a little bit, this way Maker does not need to experiment with fundamental structural changes and can adopt it once it is clear that it actually works. Again the only thing I think everyone can agree on now is 1) we need to not make drastic governance changes or add too much more “contentious” collateral types, and 2) there is at least a possibility that an approval voting system can help us fix all these problems. Once again I am in contact with both Rune and Luca and we are all at least in theory willing to work together in good faith. If you are aware of a large bloc of voters that feels that neither of these represents the best interests of Dai and the Maker system, feel free to DM me on discord and I will hear you out. Please be aware I am very much on guard for shills and sockpuppets, those kind of actors stick out like glow-in-the-dark clowns to me, it’s like I have special goggles that let me see even the tiniest bit of fluorescent material from a mile away.
content.GPT-summary: The author of the post clarifies their stance on the LOVE vs MetaDAO proposals and proposes the use of approval voting to fix the dysfunctional governance system. They also express willingness to collaborate with others and are open to feedback and criticism.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal
None

content.content: Thank you for this public message @nikolai I just want to clarify that the LOVE proposal, although in hindsight arguably under-developed, wasn’t conceived neither campaigned for as an alternative to the Endgame Plan. Those proposals have massively different scopes, ambitions, and actually could partially be contained one (LOVE) within the other. I believe there is no need for me to address publicly that I have not been involved, neither I know of anyone involved, in the MKR borrowing or in any vicious attack to you or the RAI project - of which by the way I am a massive fan. I would also add that the inference that a borrowing position would naturally be open to support change rather than protect the status quo doesn’t seem as straightforward to me. Hence, I’d prefer to remain agnostic. I have distanced myself from the day-to-day of Maker after the LOVE vote, but I remain a community member and a huge fan and supporter of the project. I have my own ideas, but I am keeping those to myself as an independent thinker for the time being. I have no affiliation to any group nor any investor that is significantly exposed to Maker. At the same time, I would be happy to provide my views and collaborate on things I believe in. I think your intentions to move away from simple majority voting is to me at the highest priority of what Maker would need. I am looking forward to hear more.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Re: borrowed MKR for LOVE vote. Can someone provide me a tx where a large amount of MKR was borrowed? If not I would like to put this rumor to bed. We have a blockchain folks, show me the money. I see two 9k MKR withdrawals from Aave and Compound on that day, but no borrowing: Whale withdraws 9k from Compound: https://ethtx.info/mainnet/0x8edb8f739d2cb5e3adb2293e9b819c511b89a4908030d69c891c3007f1332c7a/ Whale withdraws 9k from Aave: https://ethtx.info/mainnet/0x7d19d7b8303f0156c76c37393a8aff2b2ba897414dafa95f428f6e19be273120/ Both these accounts voted NO on LOVE, but that doesn’t really matter as this is their MKR it’s not borrowed. Here is their accounts and voting history respectively if you are interested: https://vote.makerdao.com/address/0x49d56a8f4f79a639d50e622ba3c83e6297b51be5#account-details https://vote.makerdao.com/address/0xBbA4C8eB57DF16c4CfAbe4e9A3Ab697A3e0C65D8#account-details It seems to me this borrowed MKR story is entirely made up. Neither side borrowed MKR. Please prove me wrong with a transaction id otherwise. Here is a list of all MKR transfers in and out of Aave around that date if you want to hunt for it yourself: https://etherscan.io/tokentxns?a=0xc713e5E149D5D0715DcD1c156a020976e7E56B88&p=4

content.content: I do see a lot of potential in approval voting for decisions with a lot of options. For example, we get a lot of RWA applications and they have mostly been voted on in a vacuum. However, each approved deal limits our ability to do othe deals. With approval voting, we could have a system where funds would flow to the top X approved arrangers/funds, with a time weighting function to prevent sudden shifts. As long as the assets are liquid, this would ensure that there is a broad support behind our RWA strategy.

content.content: The below is my personal opinion and not a RWF communication     nikolai:  I think we should do this before committing to a direction for RWA onboarding policy (but I don’t object to small case studies with responsibly low debt ceilings so that progress is not totally stalled).   Being a contributor to @Real-World-Finance since February 2021, I agree with the general statement. My only query will be to define “responsibly low”. A reasonable interpretation may be had by reference to term, counter-party risk (financial and/or experience), legal structure risk, and likely impact on the surplus buffer if there is a negative credit event. Up to now, many MIP6 applications require bespoke structuring (which takes time) and/or an imprudent mixture of the above factors. I fully support the premise that we not stall progress. This is critical as Maker has a meaningful head-start in this space. Frankly, I think “progress” is where Maker can really exercise leverage to push the envelope in a manner that traditional finance cannot (for whatever reason). What I mean is that Maker should move on from TradFi with a crypto overlay. Maker should (1) push for digitally native assets (or at least assets that are more likely to be digitized than not) and (2) focus on assets that already have (or have the potential to have) digital oracles associated with them. I think you can then layer on a “clean money” thesis as a 3rd metric. As an example (though not perfect) is an account receivable created upon the delivery of a cargo of liquefied natural gas (LNG). The account receivable is an IOU and can be easily digitally native. The LNG is electronically metered and scientifically measured by an independent 3rd party at delivery (i.e., an oracle), the LNG price will be calculated by reference to a public benchmark (Brent, TTF, Henry Hub, or JKM (i.e., an oracle)), and the buyer (typically a credit worthy entity given the $ involved) has 7-10 days to pay (short-term). There are some shortcomings with the above proposal (which I will not get into here), but directionally this is where Maker can excel. Another example may be hash-power backed loan obligations as introduced by @teej. HBLO Maker can safely push the envelope in a responsible manner and capitalize on its existing leadership role. We need to have a thoughtful discussion on the opportunities.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: I’d call it Physical Metaverse: a natural middle ground and a bridge between the worlds of purely virtual assets like crypto or gaming and purely real world assets tokenised by entities like arrangers in a trustful manner. It might actually be a superfruitful source of organic growth for Maker. One more angle: take digital design and fabrication. Emerging technologies allow a seamless digital workflow: you design a fabrication-, material-, environment-aware model of the desired built object => translate this representation, with embedded metadata corresponding to material proportions, into machine parameters for extrusion toolpaths for a 3d printer on a robotised platform => run manufacture process. Construction technologies already allowing to fabricate structures on length scales ranging from millimetres to meters are being readied for production as we speak. Parts of this workflow, both models and built environment, are born digital, data about them could be broadcast onchain trustlessly. Imo, that’s one of the paths for trustless tokenisation of real world assets. Other expressions of the emergent Physical Metaverse a.k.a. Ambient computing a.k.a. Augmented reality that in the foreseeable future could become ingredients allowing bringing value from the physical world onchain through trustless tokenisation:  work done at Google ATAP on turning physical environment into a human-computer interface integrating a miniature radar that understands human motions at various scales: from your heartbeat to the movements of your body (project Soli) and turning sewn environment from clothing and shoes to backpacks into HCI interfaces (project Jacquard);  work done at the MIT Media lab on tangible interfaces;  Dynamicland project.

content.content: nikolai:  I think we should do this before committing to a direction for RWA onboarding policy (but I don’t object to small case studies with responsibly low debt ceilings so that progress is not totally stalled). I can try to lead by example and show what approval voting for a set of delegates looks like in vivo in parallel projects for a little bit, this way Maker does not need to experiment with fundamental structural changes and can adopt it once it is clear that it actually works. Again the only thing I think everyone can agree on now is 1) we need to not make drastic governance changes or add too much more “contentious” collateral types, and 2) there is at least a possibility that an approval voting system can help us fix all these problems.   Echoing CPs points and will add: We have two simultaneous truths in RWA land:  On-chain RWAs will invariably be re-ledgered and on-boarded, we just don’t know exactly how. All of us working on this intersection know, intuitively, that we’re moving in the right direction. But the space is unlikely to develop in a predictable way. In several years the term “RWA” will be an anachronism. It will just be “assets” as everything will live on crypto rails. RWAs will not benefit from the same trust-minimization as crypto assets out of the gate.  When you consider these two in concert, as the only senior secured lender in RWA land, we can either: A) Take no balance sheet risk, wait for infrastructure to develop (years) before touching RWAs. B) Take strategic, well-aligned risks and progressively push the innovation we want to see in the world. Incentivize existing assets to be re-ledgered (ReBirth) and creating novel digitally-native assets with better oracles (Birth) CP touches on deterministic LNG receivables, one of MANY examples of Birth assets that Maker can create internally or more likely incentivize an external specialist to package and offer us. The other component, Rebirth, is today more important to progressing because it does not require new tech. To maintain momentum and maintain our edge in RWAs, we should continue onboarding RWAs in a way that ensures each deal is better than the last. Further, given that on-chaining RWAs seems to be one of the theses the market is rallying around right now, maintaining progress is critical for MKR as an asset.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: teej:  CP touches on deterministic LNG receivables, one of MANY examples of Birth assets that Maker can create   I also personally “liked” CPs comment above, but its also fair to point out that LNG is almost entirely made up of methane ( has at least 86 times more of a warming effect as a greenhouse gas than CO2 over a 20 year period )  and does not necessarily fit the proposed “Clean Money” initiative. Controversial? Absolutely. Is it what MKR token owners want? I doubt it. But I could be wrong.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: Right. I think there’s a lot of nuance wrt to LNG as “clean” energy. For example, your point about methane stands. I don’t know enough to refute it. But LNG is notably cleaner than other fossil fuels. And blanketing all fossil fuels as dirty and thus shameful is a luxury of the developed world. The question is more so: is pursuit of LNG a net good at this juncture? Some fodder:  We abandoned domestic LNG projects and pipelines due to ESG obsession. With that went energy independence. Enter War: now we are paying the price with inflation, eroding the earnings power of the lower and middle classes. Not great for the “S” of ESG. Further, the US’ premature pursuit of “clean energy” has forced us to pander to countries with horrendous human rights histories. Even worse for the “S”. Another piece, while there’s some nuance to wrt to LNG as “clean”, there’s even more nuance wrt to clean money as a core principle of the DAO. With that said, if you read the piece CP, Eric, and I wrote, there is reference to a similar receivable (inherently digital, oracle-produced) but for solar energy.    Charting a Path for RWAs Part 2: The Maker Standard   As a working example, let’s think about an oracle-driven solar receivable. The energy output of solar panels is electronically metered. That digital representation of output, combined with an oracle of the applicable $/kwH, represents a digital account receivable, a novel RWA.   CP worked in LNG for 15 years so is probably using an example that he’s an expert on. There are all kinds of novel assets that we can accelerate the creation of. The point is that many industries remain untouched by capital markets. We can make an impact.

content.content: teej:  The question is more so: is pursuit of LNG a net good at this juncture?   I mean if I can compare the current MMBtu pricing of LNG to anything, I would say its in a gigantic price market bubble due to the unfortunate political chaos in Eastern Europe (Russian gas crisis). I think I read last week that prices are up 1400% since the summer of 2020. That’s bananas for an industry that incurs cost of $200M++ just to build 1 LNG carrier. So you need to have a ton of charter arrangements in order to pay off the cost to building a carrier and when things cool down, it sure ain’t profitable and one must improvise.

content.content: flipflopflapdelegate:  I also personally “liked” CPs comment above, but its also fair to point out that LNG is almost entirely made up of methane ( has at least 86 times more of a warming effect as a greenhouse gas than CO2 over a 20 year period ) and does not necessarily fit the proposed “Clean Money” initiative.       teej:  CP worked in LNG for 15 years so is probably using an example that he’s an expert on.   I agree with you @flipflopflapdelegate. As @teej notes, it is an example that I am most familiar with. You could arguably do the same with renewable natural gas (landfill gas), solar, heat (district heating or air source heat pumps) or any other product that it is measured/metered in a transparent, scientific way. I like @pvl’s ideas above too. We need to think broadly and creatively. I wanted to further prompt that conversation.

content.content: christiancdpetersen:  it is an example that I am most familiar with.   Don’t get me wrong, I do believe examining the possibility of funding natural gas and LNG development in sub-Saharan Africa with a cleaner approach is something that can provide benefits for countries like Senegal, Mozambique, and Tanzania. Personally I’m all for investing in clean energy for African companies at scale. At the end of the day, everyone including African countries will be hit by the current climate crisis. There’s a desperate need to provide and develop clean energy infra in Africa that can also provide energy security and jobs. Its a win/win IMO.

content.content: I love to share points of view with you, I have learned a lot here, but looking for the modernization of infrastructure in emerging countries like most of Africa would not be something risky? If the companies are corrupt, how do you ensure that the financing of the infrastructure really serves that purpose? Or if a company is financed and there is really no diversion of funds by it? Whether the regulations will help us or just not help us if this happens If we look for alternatives for real-world assets, we can start with typical problems of the daily life of the worker, such as in hospitals or clinics at the time of registering a patient, medical records on servers are lost / deleted and those made by hand are misplaced, If we tokenize any medical history record and it is addressed in a contract, could it benefit us? We modernize the medical record system in such a way that a clinical history is not manipulable, thus trying to divert our attention to products that may lose their value in such a way that we also lose value or open the range of possibilities. With this we create the server and we could make contracts with clinics, hospitals or care centers.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party extending to proposal

content.content: Moi:  looking for the modernization of infrastructure in emerging countries like most of Africa would not be something risky? If the companies are corrupt, how do you ensure that the financing of the infrastructure really serves that purpose? Or if a company is financed and there is really no diversion of funds by it?   From my understanding most of the natural gas and LNG developments/exploration/production activity, has been historically dominated by a national oil company “partnership” with an international oil company. Think BP/Shell, or the Senegal Gov doing bizz w/USA, China, France, India, UAE, etc. As far as Funding capital costs—it typically involves financing across a long development cycle. It also involves both project management and “assurances” that the local authorities/govs are supportive of the project. Otherwise whats the point. All-in-all the partnership will need to find credit worthy offtakers of the NG, or LNG—so that the government and companies + lenders can begin to recover cost and generate revenues. Hence, you’ll more than likely need some serious boots on the ground by an internal project finance team.

It is very rough, don’t take it as a complete description of either Maker nor any new system. When designing the governance system at first, what kind of activity & sophistication did you expect from MKR holders? Was there an ideal MKR user persona?
